hints.content:
We can think of $(\blueD{3} \times{\maroonD{5}})\times \greenD{{2}}$ as $(\blueD{3} \times {\maroonD{5}})$ groups of $\greenD{{2}}$. That equals $\purpleC{15}$ groups of $\greenD{2}$.   

![15 groups of 2 dots. The groups are in 3 columns with 5 groups per column](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/d7d90425a1de6d9abb66baafa1e358eca49d2bd4)

How can we complete $\blueD{3} \times ({\maroonD{?}}\times {\greenD{2}})$ to get the same total?

$\blueD{3} \times ({\maroonD{?}}\times {\greenD{2}})$ can represent $\blueD{3}$ groups of $\maroonD{?}$ groups of $\greenD{2}$.

![The same dots in 3 groups of 5 groups of 2. ](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/713dc4059c8c803c8fd2088c10a3778912eb8f74)

There are $\blueD{3}$ groups of $\maroonD{5}$ groups of $\greenD{2}$.

We can change the grouping of the factors without changing the total.  

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
As long as we're only multiplying, we can group the factors in any way without changing the total product.

We call that the **associative property of multiplication**.

It does *not* work when we mix multiplication with other operations like addition.

For example:

$\begin{align}
2+(3 \times 4) &\neq (2 + 3) \times 4\\\\
2+12 &\neq 5 \times 4\\\\
14 &\neq 20
\end{align}$
